Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

“I Cracked My Google Interview with This ONE Strategy”Weeks before my first interview, I knew I had to be fully prepared. But where do you even begin when applying for a company like Google? I started with deep research!Before my InterviewI watched YouTube podcasts where former candidates shared their experiences, breaking down what to expect in each round. I read articles from career experts explaining the nuances of behavioral interviews. And then, I found blogs written by people who had sat in the very seat I was preparing for, sharing the types of questions they faced, the challenges they encountered!During my InterviewI needed a structured approach to confidently deliver my responses during the interview. I used the STAR method for answering behavioral questions with clarity and impact.For those unfamiliar with it, the STAR method helps you craft clear, structured answers:✅ Situation – Describe the context or background of the situation you were in.✅ Task – Explain the specific challenge being faced.✅ Action – Detail the steps you took to address the challenge or complete the task.✅ Result – Share the outcome of your actions, including any measurable impact.To examplify this, let us consider a situation:⚫️Situation – Our team was struggling with unorganized project updates, leading to confusion and missed deadlines.⚫️Task – I needed to streamline communication and ensure everyone stayed aligned on project progress.⚫️Action – I introduced a weekly update system using a shared dashboard, where team members could track tasks, deadlines, and blockers in real time.⚫️Result – This improved team coordination, reduced missed deadlines by 40%, and made project updates clear and efficient for everyone.Post InterviewAfter three intense interview rounds, the moment finally arrived. I opened my inbox and saw an email from Google with a positive response!Interviews can be nerve-wracking, but the STAR method gives you the confidence to own your story. Whether you’re applying to Google or any other dream company, this framework helps you structure your answers with clarity, impact, and confidence.As you prepare for your next interview, remember that confidence comes from preparation. Trust in your experiences, structure your answers with clarity, and walk in with the belief that you belong. Your next big opportunity is closer than you think!hashtag#Google hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Freshers hashtag#JobOpportunity hashtag#digitalmarketing hashtag#googleapprenticeships

Why Have Tech Interviews Become This Exhausting?Lately, every single tech job I’ve applied for follows the same rigorous hiring process:1. Screening Call – A quick chat with a recruiter.2. Technical Interview – A discussion with the hiring manager.3. Take-Home Assignment – A 7-day coding challenge (yes, all of them).4. Code Review Interview – A deep-dive discussion with multiple team members.5. Final Interview – A cultural fit check with management.I understand why this structure exists for junior or entry-level roles. But for someone like me—a senior engineer with 8+ years of experience at Rackspace, VMware, Siemens, Swisscom, and Glassdoor—why is this level of assessment necessary?These companies hired me without all the excessive hoops, and I consistently performed as a top achiever in every role. I have references, past work, and proof of my contributions. Why is that not enough?I’m over 30 now. I don’t enjoy interviews anymore. I don’t need a job just for the money—I love working in tech because it’s been part of my life since childhood. I grew up watching my dad code on what I used to call "the black screen." I wrote my first program in preparatory school, and I’ve never stopped since.So why does pursuing something I love feel like a stressful, demoralizing rollercoaster? Why should I pour my energy into a take-home assignment, knowing full well I might be rejected based on one person's subjective judgment?I’m an introvert. I don’t thrive in endless interviews. I thrive in my work.If this hiring process is the new standard, can someone explain why? Just make it make sense.hashtag#devops hashtag#sre hashtag#senior hashtag#hr hashtag#hiring hashtag#process #hashtag#takehomeassignment hashtag#passion hashtag#observability hashtag#tech hashtag#jobs hashtag#cv hashtag#hr hashtag#top hashtag#trend hashtag#Europe hashtag#recruitment hashtag#recruiter

“I Cracked My Google Interview with This ONE Strategy”Weeks before my first interview, I knew I had to be fully prepared. But where do you even begin when applying for a company like Google? I started with deep research!Before my InterviewI watched YouTube podcasts where former candidates shared their experiences, breaking down what to expect in each round. I read articles from career experts explaining the nuances of behavioral interviews. And then, I found blogs written by people who had sat in the very seat I was preparing for, sharing the types of questions they faced, the challenges they encountered!During my InterviewI needed a structured approach to confidently deliver my responses during the interview. I used the STAR method for answering behavioral questions with clarity and impact.For those unfamiliar with it, the STAR method helps you craft clear, structured answers:✅ Situation – Describe the context or background of the situation you were in.✅ Task – Explain the specific challenge being faced.✅ Action – Detail the steps you took to address the challenge or complete the task.✅ Result – Share the outcome of your actions, including any measurable impact.To examplify this, let us consider a situation:⚫️Situation – Our team was struggling with unorganized project updates, leading to confusion and missed deadlines.⚫️Task – I needed to streamline communication and ensure everyone stayed aligned on project progress.⚫️Action – I introduced a weekly update system using a shared dashboard, where team members could track tasks, deadlines, and blockers in real time.⚫️Result – This improved team coordination, reduced missed deadlines by 40%, and made project updates clear and efficient for everyone.Post InterviewAfter three intense interview rounds, the moment finally arrived. I opened my inbox and saw an email from Google with a positive response!Interviews can be nerve-wracking, but the STAR method gives you the confidence to own your story. Whether you’re applying to Google or any other dream company, this framework helps you structure your answers with clarity, impact, and confidence.As you prepare for your next interview, remember that confidence comes from preparation. Trust in your experiences, structure your answers with clarity, and walk in with the belief that you belong. Your next big opportunity is closer than you think!hashtag#Google hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Freshers hashtag#JobOpportunity hashtag#digitalmarketing hashtag#googleapprenticeships
